body: You can use `FrozenTime::setJsonEncodeFormat()` in your bootstrap to set required format.

For 4.0+, could we switch it to an expected standard in JS/JSON-World aka:
https://stackoverflow.com/a/15952652
@andrii-pukhalevych If the default string for `$_jsonEncodeFormat` has colons `:` how do they get converted to dots `.`?  Are you sure the default string isn't getting changed?

@ADmad I dind't change default json format string anywhere. 
It works correct in local version, but produces dots on production server.
In app config I have `'defaultLocale' => env('APP_DEFAULT_LOCALE', 'da_DK'),`
Locally I cant reproduce issue with php 7.0 or 7.3, icu 52 or 62.

Anyway, it shoud use `DateTime::ATOM` as default format and normal format for json, 
because json don't need locale-depended delimiters.
If the same issue doesn't occur for you locally than it's more likely an environment/configuration issue rather than a bug in the code.

Somewhere in server settings they have dots `.` for time delimiters.
But this does not mean that default `$_jsonEncodeFormat` should produce dots in json encoded time.
Found solution for this: set default format to `$_jsonEncodeFormat = "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH':'mm':'ssxxx"`
Single quotes around colons prevents locale-depended delimiters for default format, 
but still allow to override default format and uses `i18nFormat` for formatting
That's really strange, I have no idea why the format would have be set that way :slightly_smiling_face:. Hopefully someone else does.
@andrii-pukhalevych what version of php is your server running?

I could not reproduce the issue with 7.0.x.  It seems unlikely to be a php-intl or libicu bug.

If you call `FrozenTime::setJsonEncodeFormat("yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ssxxx");` using the same original format does it work? I was wondering if something was overwriting the default before you call jsonSerialize().

Perhaps it's worth submitting a bug report to php?  I looked and didn't find anything related to this.

The . and : characters are not locale-specific. They're considered escaped characters even without the ':' so that seems like a bug?
